title: Warning: This Sandy Hook Promise PSA is exceedingly difficult to watch
text:
This year’s PSA from the nonprofit group Sandy Hook Promise may be disturbing to some, if not all, viewers.

Sandy Hook Promise, formed by families whose loved ones were among the 20 children and six adults killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School mass shooting in Newtown, Conn., releases a public-service announcement each year to raise awareness about gun violence with the aim of preventing such tragedies in the future.

It’s outdone itself this time:

The 67-second PSA — titled “Back to School Essentials” — begins innocently enough, with students enthusing over their new school supplies. It takes a turn as the viewer hears the sound of gunshots in the background, and kids start running and screaming. That’s when the children start using their new school supplies to defend themselves.

“These new sneakers are just what I need for the new year,” says a boy running for his life down a hallway.

“These scissors come in handy in art class,” whispers a girl, who clutches a pair of shears as a weapon while hiding behind a door. A classmate arms himself with colored pencils.

Sandy Hook Promise/YouTube

“These new socks — they can be a real life-saver,” chimes in another girl, who ties a tourniquet on the leg of a fellow student who’s bleeding heavily.

But the most gutting scene may be the one of a girl cowering in a bathroom stall, who texts “I love you mom” to her mother. “I finally got my own phone to stay in touch with my mom,” she says through her tears — as the ominous sound of footsteps approaches her hiding place.

Sandy Hook Promise/YouTube

The spot ends: “It’s back-to-school time, and you know what that means.”

And a message that school shootings are preventable when you know the signs links to the Sandy Hook Promise website.

Nicole Hockley, a Sandy Hook Promise co-founder whose 6-year-old son Dylan was killed during the Sandy Hook shooting, told MSNBC’s Stephanie Ruhle on Wednesday that the PSA is meant to “shock parents, and say this is not what school should be about. We need to take action to prevent these.”

Hockley added that her surviving son, who is in 10th grade, practiced active shooter drills or evacuation drills in school every day last week. “I want people to be outraged by this new normal of school shootings and school violence,” she said.

The PSA struck a nerve with audiences, leading Sandy Hook Promise to trend on Twitter TWTR, +0.00% early Wednesday. Viewers called the PSA “powerful” and even “a real punch to the throat,” with many admitting it had made them cry.

This new Sandy Hook PSA is a real punch to the throat. Ooof. https://t.co/Mw0hywDQDL — J Herskowitz (@jherskowitz) September 18, 2019

I saw this. I have a young teen. He's on the spectrum.



Yes. It scares me. Yes, this made me cry. How do I let him be a kid if I have to teach him there's a chance he'll be shot?



You fucking tell me that. How?https://t.co/6cXAvBry4p — Name isn't blank (@ohmyword1) September 18, 2019

Katie Couric tweeted that 2018 was the deadliest year of gun violence on record, with 94 shooting incidents, including the Valentine’s Day shooting in Parkland, Fla., according to data from the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School. (Its K-12 School Shooting Database documents every instance in which a gun is brandished, or is fired, or a bullet hits a school property for any reason.)

2018 was the deadliest year on record with over 94 incidents of gun violence, including Parkland. This PSA from @sandyhook Promise shows the heartbreaking reality of what students go through and brings attention to Sandy Hook Promise’s impactful Know the Signs programs. https://t.co/6QkdBJpBoU — Katie Couric (@katiecouric) September 18, 2019

Joe Biden, the former vice president and current Democratic presidential candidate, included the ad in a Twitter post while calling out Senate Republicans’ “inaction on gun violence.” (Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has said he won’t bring legislation to the floor absent a signal from the White House as to which gun-control measure or measures President Trump is definitively amenable to, a posture for which his chamber’s minority leader, Chuck Schumer, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have expressed impatience.)

Another school year is starting. Another month of Senate Republicans’ inaction on gun violence. This powerful ad from my friends @sandyhook captures the physical and emotional consequences of that inaction. https://t.co/16jaVm4QNG — Joe Biden (@JoeBiden) September 18, 2019

But critics of the Sandy Hook Promise message argued that such graphic images were emotionally manipulative, complaining that “using mass murder to further political agendas is about as sick as it comes.” Others complained that the video frightened them or argued that it could be used to inspire copycat shooters.

Sandy Hook Promise should NOT use graphic images of a school shooting to get PR attention. Remember, that’s how the media creates copycat shooters! @sandyhook — JT Lewis (@thejtlewis) September 18, 2019

jeeeesus christ that's heavy-handed. it's a good point they're making but god damn my heart hurts — mishter shquidward (@mr_shquidward) September 18, 2019

There have been more mass shootings — 283 — than days this year, according to a tabulation by the nonprofit Gun Violence Archive, including the rampage in Odessa and Midland, Texas, on Aug. 31; the Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, shootings within a day of each other in early August; and a shooting at a Virginia Beach municipal building in May.
description: The “back-to-school essentials” spot sees kids using scissors and skateboards to protect themselves from an active shooter.
